awd_titl_txt: Aversion to losing? Neural mechanisms underlying the paradoxical effect of incentives on performance
awd_abstract_narration:
A common assumption is that in order to get individuals to perform better on a particular task, they should be rewarded in proportion to how well they perform. This reasoning is behind performance-based pay in the workplace.  However, psychologists and economists have long recognized that this type of relationship between rewards and performance only holds up to a point: When rewards get too large, often performance for a skilled task decreases rather than increases, compared to performance levels for a more moderate reward.  With funding from the National Science Foundation, Dr. John O'Doherty and colleagues at the California Institute of Technology are investigating why when a reward becomes especially large, individuals become very focused on the possibility of losing or failing to attain that reward. The researchers are studying whether the possibility of failure causes interference in the parts of the brain involved in performing a skilled act. The investigators are using functional magnetic brain imaging (fMRI) to measure brain activity while volunteers perform a skilled task that involves a sequence of careful hand movements for which they receive differing amounts of potential monetary rewards, ranging from small to relatively large.  The researchers are investigating whether performance levels for the larger rewards decreases relative to that for medium incentive levels, and whether decreasing brain activity in an area called the "ventral striatum" is related to individual performance decrements. In this project, the investigators are using multiple methods to manipulate how much individuals are focused on obtaining a negative and/or losing outcome while they perform the task. The researchers assert that a) the more individuals are focused on losing, the greater their performance declines; whereas, conversely, the less individuals are oriented to the possibility of losing, the greater their performance increase and that b) differences in focus are related to differing patterns of activity in the brain. 

Understanding why it is that performance sometimes decreases when the rewards (or stakes) are large has important implications in a number of areas. The knowledge gained could be used to design better schemes for incentivizing people to perform well on a work task, by minimizing the potential for performance deteriorations. More generally, many human endeavors demand high levels of performance under conditions of high stakes (high potential gain and high potential losses). Competitive sports are an obvious example, but similar scenarios likely arise in other high-pressure contexts, such as during surgery or the piloting of aircraft.  A better understanding of how and why performance decrements occur could aid the development of new strategies to minimize their impact. Dr. O'Doherty participates in the public dissemination of research findings through a variety of media, including news papers and magazines, science blogs, and radio. The present project also contributes to the scientific training of undergraduate and graduate students, and the results of the research will be incorporated into courses taught at the undergraduate and graduate level.

por.por_cntn:
In order to motivate individuals to perform a particular task it is common to offer incentives for successful performance. It is often assumed that the greater the incentive provided, the better a task will be performed. While this is true up to an extent, sometimes for incentives that are large or for outcomes that are very highly valued (such as for example winning at a sporting competition), performance can show paradoxical decrements, a phenomenon that psychologists have come to call "choking under pressure". The goal of this NSF project was to understand why it is choking occurs, and to gain insight into what happens in the brain when choking occurs.

We looked at choking in the laboratory using a simple task in which participants had to learn to make a skilled motor action (moving a ball into a target) on a computer screen, while we measured their arm movements with a movement detection camera. We then scanned participants with functional magnetic resonance imaging to measure their brain activity while participants performed this task in order for the possibility to win different amounts of money pending on their successful completion of the task. Consistent with the presence of behavioral choking effects, individuals performed less well for the largest incentive ($100) than for smaller incentives (e.g. $50). 

We found that people vary in their susceptibility to choking effects, depending on individual differences in how they react to losses compared to gains, a behavioral trait called loss aversion. Those who strongly prefer to avoid an uncertain loss compared to the prospect of an uncertain gain  (high loss aversion), react differently in choking situations compared to those who are less loss averse. Activity in a region of the brain involved in processing rewards and in driving the motivation to respond for reward, called the ventral striatum, was found to be directly involved in underpinning behavioral choking effects. Furthermore, we found that the way in which the possible incentive is framed has a very strong effect on whether or not a choking effect occurs. In some people, framing a task in terms of potential gains instead of losses makes people more susceptible to choking, while in others framing the task in terms of potential losses to be avoided compared to frames results in greater susceptibility to choking.

Finally, we looked at whether or not we could encourage people to adopt different thinking strategies in order to change their vulnerability to behavioral choking effects. Specifically, we asked individuals in one condition to think about the potential gains they might receive if they perform the task correctly, while in another condition we asked them to think about the fact that they could lose out on the amount offered if they failed on the task. This simple manipulation was also found to strongly influence the degree of susceptibility to choking effects, and this effect was once again found to involve the ventral striatum.

Taken together, our findings suggest that choking effects are strongly context dependent as they depend on how a potential outcome is framed, and that the vulnerability to choking effects various across individuals depending on behavioral factors including their loss aversion. Finally, our results suggest that a key brain region involved in reward and motivation, the ventral striatum may play a central role in underpinning the choking effect. Future work on this topic could focus on how to better implement ways to reframe potential outcomes so as to mitigate against choking effects in real world situations.
